title: Wasps back-rower Liz Crake prepared for Bristol dogfight
text:
“It’s always going to be tough to be able to compete on that level, especially when [Harlequins and Saracens] have a big draw, big-name players and contracted players – and being able to pay their players makes them much more attractive to incoming international players,” she said.

Despite the funding schism that has provoked fierce debate among fans and players of the Tyrrells Premier 15s, Crake, whose Wasps team now have a fully-funded gym, strength and conditioning coach, and physiotherapy access, believes a short-term imbalance might be necessary for long-term gain.

“You can’t say, ‘We want to go professional, have professional contracts, and be paid’ and then put a cap on it. Then we are restricting the level to which we want the game to develop. I just don’t think it’s fair to put a cap on it when this is the direction we want to go in,” she said.

“If other teams can start to get that funding, then we will all be able to move forward together, rather than restricting the teams that are [already] able to move forward.”

Crake, who started playing rugby at school in Bishop’s Stortford aged 13, has to balance work as a dentist with rugby, but says there is nothing “remarkable” about her busy schedule: “It’s a personal choice.

“This year, now that I’ve moved back [to London], I’ve cut down my hours so I’m only working two or three days a week.

“If I wanted to work full-time I could, but fortunately I’m in a profession where, although I’m not paid a huge amount as I’m a dentist for the NHS, not private, I can sacrifice my financial gains, so that I can hopefully achieve more in my rugby career.’’

Last season, Crake commuted for 2½ hours from Yeovil for matches and training sessions.

“It was what I wanted and where I wanted to be, and Wasps is the club that I wanted to stay at,” she added. ‘‘It’s what I’ve always done. It’s just what I love to do.”

Bristol Bears against Wasps today, 12noon kick-off at Shaftesbury Park, will be the first match of the season streamed live online. It will be available on Premier15s.com and England Rugby’s Facebook and YouTube channel.
description: With two wins from three matches at the start of the Tyrrells Premier 15s season, and a solid third place in the table to boot, optimism is rife at Wasps.
